content: Drink more water. Dehydration can cause your body to extract as much water as it can as foods move through your digestive tract, producing dry, hard stool. Drinking enough water will soften your stool and help things move along more easily. [1] Doctors sometimes recommend about two liters, or 8 glasses, of water per day. However, that may not be enough for you, depending on your activity level and the climate you live in. If you have frequent headaches, fatigue, dizziness, nausea, don’t urinate often, pass dark or cloudy urine, and don’t sweat much, you are probably not getting enough water. [2] Eat foods that have slight laxative effects and are high in fiber. Some of these, like prunes, have sorbitol. Sorbitol draws water into the stool, making it soft and easy to pass. [3] [4] [5] Prunes or prune juice Peaches Pears Plums Apples Apricots Raspberries Strawberries Beans Peas Spinach Eat more fiber. Fiber is the indigestible material in plant foods. Your body passes them through without absorbing them. This means that they help to produce soft, bulky stool which is easy to pass. [6] Most people don’t eat the entire recommended amount of fiber each day, which is 25 to 30 grams (0.88 to 1.1 oz). [7] You need both water soluble fiber, which turns into a gel-like material in water, and insoluble fiber, which does not dissolve. Soluble fiber is found in oats, peas, beans, apples, citrus fruits, carrots, and barley. You can get insoluble fiber in whole-wheat flour, wheat bran, nuts, beans, and vegetables like cauliflower and green beans. Many plants have both soluble and insoluble fiber, you can get both by eating lots of different grains and vegetables. Eating more fiber will be most effective if you drink extra water to help dissolve the water soluble fiber. Maintain healthy gut bacteria by eating yogurt. Your digestive tract needs the right balance of microbes to efficiently digest your food. When this microbe community gets out of balance, it can make you constipated and interfere with the absorption of nutrients. Live culture yogurt and other fermented dairy products like kefir can help restore and rebalance your gut bacteria. This can help you combat hard stools due to: [8] Irritable bowel syndrome Unexplained diarrhea and constipation Diarrhea or constipation after antibiotics have killed some of the naturally occurring gut bacteria Add supplements to your diet to promote healthy digestion. But be sure to consult your doctor first because some supplements may change how your body processes some medicines. Try fiber supplements. They will make your stool bulkier, softer and easier to pass. These supplements are often called bulk forming laxatives and you should try these before moving on to other types of laxatives. Look for ones with methylcellulose, psyllium, calcium polycarbophil, and guar gum as active ingredients (e.g., FiberCon, Metamucil, Konsyl, and Citrucel). [9] Try probiotic supplements. Probiotics are bacteria and yeasts that are like your naturally occurring gut microbes. Taking probiotics may help if you are experiencing cycles of diarrhea and constipation or irritable bowel syndrome. [10] Stimulate your bowels with a cup of coffee. Coffee can have a mild laxative effect, so adding a cup or two of coffee to your daily regimen may help to keep your bowels regular. If you already drink coffee you may either need a bit more, or your body may be too habituated for it to provide relief. Reduce your intake of foods that may cause constipation. Many of these foods are low in fiber, but high sugar and fat. This causes you to feel full before you've eaten enough fiber. Examples include: [11] [12] Milk and cheese Squash Sugary foods like pastries, puddings, candy and cake Prepackaged, processed foods which usually have added sugar, salt, and fat. [13] Eat many small meals rather than only a few large ones. Eating regularly will provide your digestive tract with continuous, low level stimulation and promote healthy digestion and regular contractions. Eat slowly to give your body time to process your food. Eating too fast makes you more likely to overeat, overwhelming your digestive system. Chew your food thoroughly to promote easy digestion and moderate portion sizes. Exercise for at least 30 minutes per day. Exercise will stimulate your bowels to contract, moving food through your system. [14] The activity should be strenuous enough to increase your heart rate like fast walking, swimming, running, or biking. Sometimes this works surprisingly quickly. Plan a route with frequent bathrooms available! If you have other health concerns that might make exercise inadvisable, talk to your doctor first. Reduce stress in your life. Stress has been shown to cause constipation and diarrhea, both of which may accompany hard, dry stools. Try relaxation techniques such as: [15] Deep breathing Yoga Meditation Tai chi Massage Listening to relaxing music Visualizing relaxing locations Progressive muscle relaxation where you go through your body and deliberately tense and release each muscle group Give yourself time on the toilet after each meal. You can simultaneously do relaxation techniques to promote movement through your system. [16] [17] [18] Spend at least 10 minutes on the toilet approximately 30 minutes after eating. Put your feet on a low stool, so your knees are above your hips. This may make the bowel movement easier. Use biofeedback to learn to release your pelvic floor muscles. This can make bowel movements easier. [19] The therapist will use a machine to measure the tension in your rectum and help you practice tightening and releasing your pelvic floor muscles. Go to a therapist that works with a doctor or is recommended by your doctor to be sure that they are reliable. Consult your doctor. Some prescription medications can cause constipation, such as opioid pain relievers. Your doctor may recommend changing your medication or adding a laxative to counter constipation. Your doctor may recommend either over-the-counter medicines or prescribe something stronger. See your doctor right away if you have: [20] Rectal bleeding Severe weight loss Fatigue Severe abdominal pain Lubricate your bowels with a small amount of mineral oil. Consult your doctor to determine what the right dose is for you. [21] [22] Wait at least two hours after eating because it may prevent you from fully absorbing the nutrients. It will work within the next six to eight hours. Do not take it while lying in bed, because if you accidentally inhale some of it, it can cause pneumonia in your lungs. For this reason, do not give it to children younger than seven. Do not take mineral oil if you are pregnant, as it may prevent the uptake of nutrients and cause bleeding in the newborn if taken for a long time. Try stool softeners. These medications take moisture out of the intestines and use it to make your stool wetter. [23] Common ones include Colace and Surfak. Drink an extra few glasses to water each day when you take them. Use osmotic laxatives to make your stool wetter. These medications work by generating more liquid in your intestines. This will also stimulate your intestines to contract and move stool along, though it may take a few days. Common ones include: [24] [25] Milk of magnesia Magnesium citrate Lactulose Polyethylene glycol (MiraLax) Consider stimulant laxatives. These are useful if your stool is soft enough to pass, but your intestines aren’t contracting to move it through. These medications stimulate contractions and should work within 12 hours. Common ones are: [26] Senna Bisacodyl Sodium Picosulphate Remove a fecal impaction. If your rectum is blocked with hard, dry stool, you can get relief from a suppository, enema, or manual disimpaction. [27] [28] A suppository is a capsule of medication that you put in your anus where it dissolves and is absorbed. An enema is a liquid medication that is introduced into the large intestine via the anus. This should be done by the doctor. Manual disimpaction requires your doctor or nurse to put on gloves and insert two lubricated fingers into the rectum to break up and remove impacted feces. [29]

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Soften-Hard-Stools">How to Soften Hard Stools</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Chris M. Matsko, MD</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Softening_Stool_through_Diet_sub" id="">Softening Stool through Diet</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Making_Lifestyle_Changes_sub" id="">Making Lifestyle Changes</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Using_Medications_sub" id="">Using Medications</a>
<a class="" href="#Questions_and_Answers_sub" id="qa_toc">Questions & Answers</a>
<a class="" href="#relatedwikihows" id="rwh_toc">Related Articles</a>
<a class="toc_ref" href="#references" id="">References</a>
</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=chrism.matsko%2Cmd#chrism.matsko%2Cmd">Chris M. Matsko, MD</a>. Dr. Matsko is a retired Physician in Pennsylvania. He received his M.D. from the Temple University School of Medicine in 2007.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">29 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Passing hard, dry stool is painful. It hurts when it blocks your bowels and when it is difficult to pass. There are several dietary and lifestyle changes that will likely help solve the problem. If they don’t work, see a doctor to get something stronger.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Softening_Stool_through_Diet_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Softening_Stool_through_Diet">Softening Stool through Diet</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/09/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_1242ca7ce1" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1242ca7ce1')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/09/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Drink more water.</b> Dehydration can cause your body to extract as much water as it can as foods move through your digestive tract, producing dry, hard stool. Drinking enough water will soften your stool and help things move along more easily.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Doctors sometimes recommend about two liters, or 8 glasses, of water per day. However, that may not be enough for you, depending on your activity level and the climate you live in.</li>
<li>If you have frequent headaches, fatigue, dizziness, nausea, don’t urinate often, pass dark or cloudy urine, and don’t sweat much, you are probably not getting enough water.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-2-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-2-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_4f8a55ac7d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4f8a55ac7d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Eat foods that have slight laxative effects and are high in fiber.</b> Some of these, like prunes, have sorbitol. Sorbitol draws water into the stool, making it soft and easy to pass.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Prunes or prune juice</li>
<li>Peaches</li>
<li>Pears</li>
<li>Plums</li>
<li>Apples</li>
<li>Apricots</li>
<li>Raspberries</li>
<li>Strawberries</li>
<li>Beans</li>
<li>Peas</li>
<li>Spinach</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_9da68b0581" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9da68b0581')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Eat more fiber.</b> Fiber is the indigestible material in plant foods. Your body passes them through without absorbing them. This means that they help to produce soft, bulky stool which is easy to pass.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Most people don’t eat the entire recommended amount of fiber each day, which is 25 to 30 grams (0.88 to 1.1 oz).<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup> You need both water soluble fiber, which turns into a gel-like material in water, and insoluble fiber, which does not dissolve.</li>
<li>Soluble fiber is found in oats, peas, beans, apples, citrus fruits, carrots, and barley.</li>
<li>You can get insoluble fiber in whole-wheat flour, wheat bran, nuts, beans, and vegetables like cauliflower and green beans.</li>
<li>Many plants have both soluble and insoluble fiber, you can get both by eating lots of different grains and vegetables.</li>
<li>Eating more fiber will be most effective if you drink extra water to help dissolve the water soluble fiber.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/48/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_bd3ddbfc09" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_bd3ddbfc09')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/48/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Maintain healthy gut bacteria by eating yogurt.</b> Your digestive tract needs the right balance of microbes to efficiently digest your food. When this microbe community gets out of balance, it can make you constipated and interfere with the absorption of nutrients. Live culture yogurt and other fermented dairy products like kefir can help restore and rebalance your gut bacteria. This can help you combat hard stools due to:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Irritable bowel syndrome</li>
<li>Unexplained diarrhea and constipation</li>
<li>Diarrhea or constipation after antibiotics have killed some of the naturally occurring gut bacteria</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_e7b234baa5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e7b234baa5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add supplements to your diet to promote healthy digestion.</b> But be sure to consult your doctor first because some supplements may change how your body processes some medicines.

<ul>
<li>Try fiber supplements. They will make your stool bulkier, softer and easier to pass. These supplements are often called bulk forming laxatives and you should try these before moving on to other types of laxatives. Look for ones with methylcellulose, psyllium, calcium polycarbophil, and guar gum as active ingredients (e.g., FiberCon, Metamucil, Konsyl, and Citrucel).<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Try probiotic supplements. Probiotics are bacteria and yeasts that are like your naturally occurring gut microbes. Taking probiotics may help if you are experiencing cycles of diarrhea and constipation or irritable bowel syndrome.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_4d801cb8cd" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4d801cb8cd')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Stimulate your bowels with a cup of coffee.</b> Coffee can have a mild laxative effect, so adding a cup or two of coffee to your daily regimen may help to keep your bowels regular.

<ul>
<li>If you already drink coffee you may either need a bit more, or your body may be too habituated for it to provide relief.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Making_Lifestyle_Changes_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Making_Lifestyle_Changes">Making Lifestyle Changes</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_02af1a2ba3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_02af1a2ba3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Reduce your intake of foods that may cause constipation.</b> Many of these foods are low in fiber, but high sugar and fat. This causes you to feel full before you've eaten enough fiber. Examples include:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Milk and cheese</li>
<li>Squash</li>
<li>Sugary foods like pastries, puddings, candy and cake</li>
<li>Prepackaged, processed foods which usually have added sugar, salt, and fat.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-8-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-8-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_de88791a33" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_de88791a33')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Eat many small meals rather than only a few large ones.</b> Eating regularly will provide your digestive tract with continuous, low level stimulation and promote healthy digestion and regular contractions.

<ul>
<li>Eat slowly to give your body time to process your food. Eating too fast makes you more likely to overeat, overwhelming your digestive system.</li>
<li>Chew your food thoroughly to promote easy digestion and moderate portion sizes.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-9-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-9-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_9b3700b20b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9b3700b20b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Exercise for at least 30 minutes per day.</b> Exercise will stimulate your bowels to contract, moving food through your system.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>The activity should be strenuous enough to increase your heart rate like fast walking, swimming, running, or biking.</li>
<li>Sometimes this works surprisingly quickly. Plan a route with frequent bathrooms available!</li>
<li>If you have other health concerns that might make exercise inadvisable, talk to your doctor first.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-10-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-10-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e3/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_7bc7a7b9ce" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7bc7a7b9ce')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e3/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Reduce stress in your life.</b> Stress has been shown to cause constipation and diarrhea, both of which may accompany hard, dry stools. Try relaxation techniques such as:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Deep breathing</li>
<li>Yoga</li>
<li>Meditation</li>
<li>Tai chi</li>
<li>Massage</li>
<li>Listening to relaxing music</li>
<li>Visualizing relaxing locations</li>
<li>Progressive muscle relaxation where you go through your body and deliberately tense and release each muscle group</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-11-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-11-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_716d675455" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_716d675455')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Give yourself time on the toilet after each meal.</b> You can simultaneously do relaxation techniques to promote movement through your system.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Spend at least 10 minutes on the toilet approximately 30 minutes after eating.</li>
<li>Put your feet on a low stool, so your knees are above your hips. This may make the bowel movement easier.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-12-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-12-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_6467229233" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_6467229233')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use biofeedback to learn to release your pelvic floor muscles.</b> This can make bowel movements easier.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>The therapist will use a machine to measure the tension in your rectum and help you practice tightening and releasing your pelvic floor muscles.</li>
<li>Go to a therapist that works with a doctor or is recommended by your doctor to be sure that they are reliable.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Using_Medications_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Using_Medications">Using Medications</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-13.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_104743fecb" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_104743fecb')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-13.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consult your doctor.</b> Some prescription medications can cause constipation, such as opioid pain relievers. Your doctor may recommend changing your medication or adding a laxative to counter constipation. Your doctor may recommend either over-the-counter medicines or prescribe something stronger. See your doctor right away if you have:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Rectal bleeding</li>
<li>Severe weight loss</li>
<li>Fatigue</li>
<li>Severe abdominal pain</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-14.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_d114e5f8cc" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d114e5f8cc')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-14.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Lubricate your bowels with a small amount of mineral oil.</b> Consult your doctor to determine what the right dose is for you.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 21" class="reference" id="_ref-21"><a href="#_note-21">[21]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 22" class="reference" id="_ref-22"><a href="#_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Wait at least two hours after eating because it may prevent you from fully absorbing the nutrients.</li>
<li>It will work within the next six to eight hours.</li>
<li>Do not take it while lying in bed, because if you accidentally inhale some of it, it can cause pneumonia in your lungs. For this reason, do not give it to children younger than seven.</li>
<li>Do not take mineral oil if you are pregnant, as it may prevent the uptake of nutrients and cause bleeding in the newborn if taken for a long time.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-15.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_f89f492462" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f89f492462')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-15.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try stool softeners.</b> These medications take moisture out of the intestines and use it to make your stool wetter.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 23" class="reference" id="_ref-23"><a href="#_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Common ones include Colace and Surfak.</li>
<li>Drink an extra few glasses to water each day when you take them.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-16.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-16.jpg" height="546" id="img_634367a088" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_634367a088')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-16.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use osmotic laxatives to make your stool wetter.</b> These medications work by generating more liquid in your intestines. This will also stimulate your intestines to contract and move stool along, though it may take a few days. Common ones include:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 24" class="reference" id="_ref-24"><a href="#_note-24">[24]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 25" class="reference" id="_ref-25"><a href="#_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Milk of magnesia</li>
<li>Magnesium citrate</li>
<li>Lactulose</li>
<li>Polyethylene glycol (MiraLax)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-17.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-17.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-17.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-17.jpg" height="546" id="img_667150de8a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_667150de8a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-17.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-17.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider stimulant laxatives.</b> These are useful if your stool is soft enough to pass, but your intestines aren’t contracting to move it through. These medications stimulate contractions and should work within 12 hours. Common ones are:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 26" class="reference" id="_ref-26"><a href="#_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Senna</li>
<li>Bisacodyl</li>
<li>Sodium Picosulphate</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-18.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5511044" href="#/Image:Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-18.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-18.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-18.jpg" height="546" id="img_12e004a295" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_12e004a295')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Soften Hard Stools Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-18.jpg/aid5511044-v4-728px-Soften-Hard-Stools-Step-18.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Remove a fecal impaction.</b> If your rectum is blocked with hard, dry stool, you can get relief from a suppository, enema, or manual disimpaction.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 27" class="reference" id="_ref-27"><a href="#_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 28" class="reference" id="_ref-28"><a href="#_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>A suppository is a capsule of medication that you put in your anus where it dissolves and is absorbed.</li>
<li>An enema is a liquid medication that is introduced into the large intestine via the anus. This should be done by the doctor.</li>
<li>Manual disimpaction requires your doctor or nurse to put on gloves and insert two lubricated fingers into the rectum to break up and remove impacted feces.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 29" class="reference" id="_ref-29"><a href="#_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="5511044" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs qa_waittheresmore" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="193524" data-caid="194397" data-cqid="193541" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="794842" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105116" data-votes_down="4" data-votes_up="50">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can hard stools cause bleeding?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=chrism.matsko%2Cmd#chrism.matsko%2Cmd" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/3/3e/Chris-M.-Matsko.jpg/-crop-200-200-200px-Chris-M.-Matsko.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=chrism.matsko%2Cmd#chrism.matsko%2Cmd" target="_blank">Chris M. Matsko, MD</a><br/>
	Family Medicine Physician
</div>
Dr. Matsko is a retired Physician in Pennsylvania. He received his M.D. from the Temple University School of Medicine in 2007.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=chrism.matsko%2Cmd#chrism.matsko%2Cmd" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/3/3e/Chris-M.-Matsko.jpg/-crop-200-200-200px-Chris-M.-Matsko.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=chrism.matsko%2Cmd#chrism.matsko%2Cmd" target="_blank">Chris M. Matsko, MD</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Family Medicine Physician</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Yes, hard stools can cause hemorrhoids and bleeding due to the increase in pressure that results from pushing.  
</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>4</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>50</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="193526" data-caid="194399" data-cqid="193543" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1073093" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105116" data-votes_down="5" data-votes_up="34">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Which suppository should I use to release impaction?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=chrism.matsko%2Cmd#chrism.matsko%2Cmd" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/3/3e/Chris-M.-Matsko.jpg/-crop-200-200-200px-Chris-M.-Matsko.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=chrism.matsko%2Cmd#chrism.matsko%2Cmd" target="_blank">Chris M. Matsko, MD</a><br/>
	Family Medicine Physician
</div>
Dr. Matsko is a retired Physician in Pennsylvania. He received his M.D. from the Temple University School of Medicine in 2007.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=chrism.matsko%2Cmd#chrism.matsko%2Cmd" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/3/3e/Chris-M.-Matsko.jpg/-crop-200-200-200px-Chris-M.-Matsko.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=chrism.matsko%2Cmd#chrism.matsko%2Cmd" target="_blank">Chris M. Matsko, MD</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Family Medicine Physician</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">If you are impacted you need to see a surgeon.  You may have to get manually disimpacted.  I do not recommend explosive medication to relieve your situation, as this can cause harm.  
</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="315611" data-caid="316484" data-cqid="315628" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1530867" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="3" data-votes_up="16">

<div class="qa_q_txt question">I have a lot of pain in my anus from the bleeding. What should I do?</div>

<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="458213" data-caid="459086" data-cqid="458230" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2473634" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="5">

<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Whenever I'm constipated, it normally takes over a week for me to pass it. How can I make passing it hurt less when I'm actually on the toilet?</div>

<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>

            "@type": "HowToSection",

            "position": 1,

                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Drink more water. Dehydration can cause your body to extract as much water as it can as foods move through your digestive tract, producing dry, hard stool. Drinking enough water will soften your stool and help things move along more easily.[1]\nDoctors sometimes recommend about two liters, or 8 glasses, of water per day. However, that may not be enough for you, depending on your activity level and the climate you live in.\nIf you have frequent headaches, fatigue, dizziness, nausea, don\u2019t urinate often, pass dark or cloudy urine, and don\u2019t sweat much, you are probably not getting enough water.[2]"
                    }

This should be done by the doctor.\nManual disimpaction requires your doctor or nurse to put on gloves and insert two lubricated fingers into the rectum to break up and remove impacted feces.[29]"

title: How to Soften Hard Stools
content_html:
Drink more water. Dehydration can cause your body to extract as much water as it can as foods move through your digestive tract, producing dry, hard stool. Drinking enough water will soften your stool and help things move along more easily.[1]
  • Doctors sometimes recommend about two liters, or 8 glasses, of water per day. However, that may not be enough for you, depending on your activity level and the climate you live in.
  • If you have frequent headaches, fatigue, dizziness, nausea, don’t urinate often, pass dark or cloudy urine, and don’t sweat much, you are probably not getting enough water.[2]
Eat foods that have slight laxative effects and are high in fiber. Some of these, like prunes, have sorbitol. Sorbitol draws water into the stool, making it soft and easy to pass.[3][4][5]
  • Prunes or prune juice
  • Peaches
  • Pears
  • Plums
  • Apples
  • Apricots
  • Raspberries
  • Strawberries
  • Beans
  • Peas
  • Spinach
Eat more fiber. Fiber is the indigestible material in plant foods. Your body passes them through without absorbing them. This means that they help to produce soft, bulky stool which is easy to pass.[6]
  • Most people don’t eat the entire recommended amount of fiber each day, which is 25 to 30 grams (0.88 to 1.1 oz).[7] You need both water soluble fiber, which turns into a gel-like material in water, and insoluble fiber, which does not dissolve.
  • Soluble fiber is found in oats, peas, beans, apples, citrus fruits, carrots, and barley.
  • You can get insoluble fiber in whole-wheat flour, wheat bran, nuts, beans, and vegetables like cauliflower and green beans.
  • Many plants have both soluble and insoluble fiber, you can get both by eating lots of different grains and vegetables.
  • Eating more fiber will be most effective if you drink extra water to help dissolve the water soluble fiber.
Maintain healthy gut bacteria by eating yogurt. Your digestive tract needs the right balance of microbes to efficiently digest your food. When this microbe community gets out of balance, it can make you constipated and interfere with the absorption of nutrients. Live culture yogurt and other fermented dairy products like kefir can help restore and rebalance your gut bacteria. This can help you combat hard stools due to:[8]
  • Irritable bowel syndrome
  • Unexplained diarrhea and constipation
  • Diarrhea or constipation after antibiotics have killed some of the naturally occurring gut bacteria
Add supplements to your diet to promote healthy digestion. But be sure to consult your doctor first because some supplements may change how your body processes some medicines.
  • Try fiber supplements. They will make your stool bulkier, softer and easier to pass. These supplements are often called bulk forming laxatives and you should try these before moving on to other types of laxatives. Look for ones with methylcellulose, psyllium, calcium polycarbophil, and guar gum as active ingredients (e.g., FiberCon, Metamucil, Konsyl, and Citrucel).[9]
  • Try probiotic supplements. Probiotics are bacteria and yeasts that are like your naturally occurring gut microbes. Taking probiotics may help if you are experiencing cycles of diarrhea and constipation or irritable bowel syndrome.[10]
Stimulate your bowels with a cup of coffee. Coffee can have a mild laxative effect, so adding a cup or two of coffee to your daily regimen may help to keep your bowels regular.
  • If you already drink coffee you may either need a bit more, or your body may be too habituated for it to provide relief.
Reduce your intake of foods that may cause constipation. Many of these foods are low in fiber, but high sugar and fat. This causes you to feel full before you've eaten enough fiber. Examples include:[11][12]
  • Milk and cheese
  • Squash
  • Sugary foods like pastries, puddings, candy and cake
  • Prepackaged, processed foods which usually have added sugar, salt, and fat.[13]
Eat many small meals rather than only a few large ones. Eating regularly will provide your digestive tract with continuous, low level stimulation and promote healthy digestion and regular contractions.
  • Eat slowly to give your body time to process your food. Eating too fast makes you more likely to overeat, overwhelming your digestive system.
  • Chew your food thoroughly to promote easy digestion and moderate portion sizes.
Exercise for at least 30 minutes per day. Exercise will stimulate your bowels to contract, moving food through your system.[14]
  • The activity should be strenuous enough to increase your heart rate like fast walking, swimming, running, or biking.
  • Sometimes this works surprisingly quickly. Plan a route with frequent bathrooms available!
  • If you have other health concerns that might make exercise inadvisable, talk to your doctor first.
Reduce stress in your life. Stress has been shown to cause constipation and diarrhea, both of which may accompany hard, dry stools. Try relaxation techniques such as:[15]
  • Deep breathing
  • Yoga
  • Meditation
  • Tai chi
  • Massage
  • Listening to relaxing music
  • Visualizing relaxing locations
  • Progressive muscle relaxation where you go through your body and deliberately tense and release each muscle group
Give yourself time on the toilet after each meal. You can simultaneously do relaxation techniques to promote movement through your system.[16][17][18]
  • Spend at least 10 minutes on the toilet approximately 30 minutes after eating.
  • Put your feet on a low stool, so your knees are above your hips. This may make the bowel movement easier.
Use biofeedback to learn to release your pelvic floor muscles. This can make bowel movements easier.[19]
  • The therapist will use a machine to measure the tension in your rectum and help you practice tightening and releasing your pelvic floor muscles.
  • Go to a therapist that works with a doctor or is recommended by your doctor to be sure that they are reliable.
Consult your doctor. Some prescription medications can cause constipation, such as opioid pain relievers. Your doctor may recommend changing your medication or adding a laxative to counter constipation. Your doctor may recommend either over-the-counter medicines or prescribe something stronger. See your doctor right away if you have:[20]
  • Rectal bleeding
  • Severe weight loss
  • Fatigue
  • Severe abdominal pain
Lubricate your bowels with a small amount of mineral oil. Consult your doctor to determine what the right dose is for you.[21][22]
  • Wait at least two hours after eating because it may prevent you from fully absorbing the nutrients.
  • It will work within the next six to eight hours.
  • Do not take it while lying in bed, because if you accidentally inhale some of it, it can cause pneumonia in your lungs. For this reason, do not give it to children younger than seven.
  • Do not take mineral oil if you are pregnant, as it may prevent the uptake of nutrients and cause bleeding in the newborn if taken for a long time.
Try stool softeners. These medications take moisture out of the intestines and use it to make your stool wetter.[23]
  • Common ones include Colace and Surfak.
  • Drink an extra few glasses to water each day when you take them.
Use osmotic laxatives to make your stool wetter. These medications work by generating more liquid in your intestines. This will also stimulate your intestines to contract and move stool along, though it may take a few days. Common ones include:[24][25]
  • Milk of magnesia
  • Magnesium citrate
  • Lactulose
  • Polyethylene glycol (MiraLax)
Consider stimulant laxatives. These are useful if your stool is soft enough to pass, but your intestines aren’t contracting to move it through. These medications stimulate contractions and should work within 12 hours. Common ones are:[26]
  • Senna
  • Bisacodyl
  • Sodium Picosulphate
Remove a fecal impaction. If your rectum is blocked with hard, dry stool, you can get relief from a suppository, enema, or manual disimpaction.[27][28]
  • A suppository is a capsule of medication that you put in your anus where it dissolves and is absorbed.
  • An enema is a liquid medication that is introduced into the large intestine via the anus. This should be done by the doctor.
  • Manual disimpaction requires your doctor or nurse to put on gloves and insert two lubricated fingers into the rectum to break up and remove impacted feces.[29]
